Premise 1: If P (the doll was plastic), then Q (the truck was metal)
Conclusion: If Q (the truck was metal), then P (the doll was plastic)

To determine if this argument is logically valid, we need to check if the conclusion logically follows from the premise. In other words, we need to see if the argument preserves truth.

To do this, we can use a truth table, which is a table that shows all possible combinations of truth values for the premise and the conclusion.

Here's the truth table for this argument:

| P (doll was plastic) | Q (truck was metal) | P -> Q | Q -> P | (P -> Q) -> (Q -> P) |
|----------------------|---------------------|-------|-------|---------------------|
| True                 | True                | True  | True  | True                |
| True                 | False               | False | False | False               |
| False                | True                | True  | False | False               |
| False                | False               | True  | True  | True                |

As we can see from the truth table, the argument is not logically valid because there is at least one case where the premise is true, and the conclusion is false (the second row).
